Line-dependent veiling in very active T Tauri Stars
The T Tauri stars with active accretion disks show veiled photospheric spectra. This is supposedly due to non-photospheric continuum radiated by hot spots beneath the accretion shocks at stellar...

Les valeurs du chi**2 sont homogenes ce qui est plutot bon signe. Pourquoi log(g)=3.5 ? En general pour les etoiles jeunes, on prend plutot log(g)=4.0 ou 4.5.

L’elargissement des raies photospheriques est la somme quadratique de la largeur des differentes composantes soit: fwhm^2 = s0^2 + vmic^2 + vmac^2 + vsini^2 en negligeant le champ magnetique (negligeable en effet ici), et ou s0 est la largeur du profil instrumental (la resolution spectrale, R = 68,000 pour ESPaDOnS je crois, soit s0 = c/R ~ 4.4 km/s). Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-04-01 14:33:21

*Thread Reply:* Oui ces fenêtres paraissent assez mal normalisées sur certaines observations. C'est dû à la méthode de normalisation : j'ai fitté un seul spectre à la main, puis le reste des spectres à été normalisé automatiquement avec les mêmes paramètres que le premier. Si le but était de déterminer un veiling de façon très précise, je normaliserait à la main chaque fenêtre, spectre par spectre. Ici, un sigma clipping permettra d'éliminer les valeurs trop aberrantes et la moyenne restante devrait permettre d'obtenir un veiling suffisamment précis pour ce que l'on veut en faire. A voir donc en fonction du résultat du sigma clipping. Pour ce qui est des telluriques, elles ne semblent pas être trop gênantes au vu de la dispersion des fenêtres concernées

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-04-01 14:46:39

*Thread Reply:* tu dois pouvoir normaliser automatiquement chaque spectre indviduellement avec une routine qui selectionne par exemple les 10% de pixels de + forte intensite et fitte un polynome a ces pixels. Une bonne normalisation du continu est assez critique pour le calcul du veiling.

Jerome Bouvier (jerome.bouvier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-04-29 18:54:54

That the average profile is asymmetric is presumably a sampling effect, i.e., averaging of few profiles that are all strongly asymmetric yields a mean profile that does not really reflect the (presumably symmetric) intrinsic profile. What is very astonishing in your time series, is that the I profile goes from left to right and back on a timescale of 1 night or less. Usually these deformations are due to surface spots, but this would indicate a rotational period of a day or less, which i doubt is the case (i don’t recall what vsini is). Here, the deformation of the I profiles is probably not due (solely) to spots, but to intrinsic variability (e.g., changing accretion spot luminosity due to non steady accretion).

2020-04-29 23:38:48

Salut à tous, the S CrA results look pretty interesting! The Stokes V detections look pretty clean. The asymmetry in the average Stokes I profile is most likely due to the very strong variability in the profile, and the phases going into the average not being perfectly evenly distributed. So some phase (with an asymmetric profile) is over-represented in the average. With such strong variability it probably doesn't take much uneven phase sampling to produce an asymmetric average. So I agree with Jerome that's the simplest explanation. An alternate hypothesis could be that there is some emission infilling in some lines of the LSD mask. If that were asymmetric it could also throw off the average. I guess you could test that by computing a model LSD 'spectrum' (from the convolution of the profile and mask), then go through by eye to check for lines where the observation has a discrepant shape.

Evelyne (evelyne.alecian@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)

2020-04-30 00:18:03

There is some very strong equivalent width variability in the Stokes I profiles. Do we know if that is consistent with veiling (continuum emission so all lines should behave the same), or if there is still some residual line emission (only some lines vary in equivalent width)? It's probably not just temperature spots in the stellar photosphere. (You've probably thought veiling that some, but haven't read the entire thread!)

Evelyne (evelyne.alecian@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-04-30 09:19:10

*Thread Reply:* Yes, Hugo has fitted the spectrum and measured the veiling that is high and does vary a lot. See the plot he posted on April 1st. So we will have to correct the profiles from veiling. What I usually do is to re-normalise all LSD profiles so that all I profiles have the same equivalent width. This is something we can do when the spots affect only slightly the EW, but here this is not the case, with the huge spots we have at some phases. The other solution would be to use the veiling values measured on the spectra to correct the LSD profiles, but how can we be sure that those values are not affected by the spots ? And also, are they precise enough ? Any thoughts are welcome !

2020-04-30 00:40:21

The rapid variability in Stokes I shape is pretty notable. Particularly in comparison to Stokes V, which doesn't change much (seems like a fairly dipolar, probably fairly axi-symmetric field). I'm not sure how to interpret the I profilel shape variability, at a glance. Do we have a good litterature rotation period? It seems like features cross the line in 1 or 2 days (trying to correct for the equivelant width variability by eye!), so if it is rotational modulation the rotation period is probably double that, 4 days at most. (We don't have multiple observations on the same night do we?) At any rate, the I profile varies pretty fast for a fairly modest vsini. So it might be hard to explain as just rotation (and tricky to map spots with DI).

Evelyne (evelyne.alecian@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-04-30 09:36:42

*Thread Reply:* Yes, I agree with the dipolar field. We are also probably seeing the star under a relatively low inclination, which would explain the fact that the shape does not vary much as the star rotates, and also that we see only one magnetic pole. There is no good literature period (based on deep photometric data). There is one measurement based on the variability of the spectral lines that gives 4.2 d, which appears relatively consistent with what we have. Hugo will compute some periodogram to see what we get. Yes, I agree, DI may be difficult. What I find strange is that we don’t see clear Stokes V signatures associated to the spots. With such strong spots we would expect associated strong V signatures that vary in radial velocity with the spot, no ?

2020-05-04 19:00:13

Ok that makes some sense. The observations are sampled pretty evenly, so the Nyquist frequency (1/2 the sampling frequency) is a useful approximation. In that case everything with a frequency above 0.5 d^-1 gets aliased. For the paper I'd suggest only plotting f <= 0.5. (Sure higher frequencies might exist and their power wold get aliased into this range, but the hope is rotation is the dominant frequency and it's hopefully below 0.5 d^-1).

2020-05-04 19:41:29

From a mapping perspective, veiling presumably does come from a (very) hot spot, but it's pretty hard to include self-consistently in a DI model, as far as I understand. The problem being that veiling material is much hotter than the photosphere and doesn't have the many of the same absorption lines (indeed we have excluded emission lines, which are more likely from the veiling region). So we have no sensitivity to the physical geometry of the veiling material (only its continuum emission). Then it's a very big assumption that the bright/warm photospheric spots (still much cooler than an accretion shock!) correspond spatially to the veiling material. And even then you would need an ad-hoc function to go from the brightness/temperature in a photospheric spot to the brightness/temperature in the veiling material. That's a long way of saying I think photospheric bright spots and veiling hot spots are two fairly different things!

2020-05-06 05:27:29

Well I'm not really an expert on veiling, just ZDI. So here is my long winded thought process 😉 I think the physical properties of the kind of bright spots mapped by DI are very different from the material veiling S CrA. In DI, bright spots are locally maybe double the brightness of neighboring regions at most, so 20% hotter tops. That's not hot enough to change line strengths dramatically, and these bright spots don't cover much of the star, so there isn't much (real) variability in equivalent widths. To get a veiling flux that changes equivalent widths by a factor of ~3 in S CrA, veiling flux should triple the regular photospheric flux (even more if it contributes some to the absorption lines), despite (presumably) being from a small region. So it must be very hot, several times hotter than the rest of the photosphere at minimum. That's why I say we are talking about fairly different kinds of spots.

From a (Z)DI perspective, the big question is what are the spectroscopic properties of the material in question. If it's spectrum is a lot different from the quiet photospheric spectrum then it either can't be modeled or need to be modeled separately using different lines.

For ZDI results I'm mostly thinking about J-F's results for T Tauri stars, where there is usually a dark spot (according to photospheric absorption lines) in the region where accretion material presumably is landing. That seems to correspond to the magnetic poles/spots. And seems to correspond to Ca II emission in the IRT. (e.g. GQ Lup, Donati et al 2012; DN Tau, Donati et al 2013; LkCa 15, Donati et al 2019) The Ca II emission can't be from exactly the same material as the Fe I absorption, but it could be chromospheric or it could be accreting material (I guess post-shock).

I don't have any particular hypothesis about where the (optical) veiling material is. I'm certainly willing to believe that, from the perspective of an accretion disk, it is close enough to the photosphere that the difference doesn't mater. (Maybe it even reaches an optical depth of unity making definitions messy?) My wild guess would be that the veiling material is just above the rest of the photosphere, maybe at the height of the chromosphere, maybe around the Ca II emission J-F finds (although I would not bet money on any of that!) But my main point is that, for the purpose of calculating model spectral lines, you need to do something more sophisticated than increasing the brightness localy (keeping the local spectrum constant). And I think more sophisticated than using a local model atmosphere in LTE with a higher effective temperature.

Thinking about possible reference stars, an alternate well studied star is 61 Cyg A. It has published ZDI results (Boro Saikia et al. 2016, 2018). It has a Teff of ~4500 K (spectroscopic) or 4374 K (interferometric), so maybe a bit hotter but not too far off, logg is probably a bit higher too. Metallicity may be a bit lower [Fe/H] = -0.3, but not dramatically low. (For a discussion of physical parameters see Heiter et al. 2015) Since it has an interferometric radius, Sudeshna inferred vsini < 0.94 km/s, which is the big advantage of using this star (with their i, vsini=0.92 km/s). The magnetic field is weak and the star isn't obviously spotted. I think for those two papers, Sudeshna used an older version of J-F Donati's ZDI code with Gaussian line profiles, so you would need to re-fit line broadening parameters anyway. So apart from the slightly lower metallicity and maybe higher Teff, it is a very good reference candidate. Really either star should work (or you could try both if you have the time!).

2020-05-19 18:10:18

Good to see the progress! For the line strengths, #3 looks a lot better to me, I would favour something around that. One thing about brightness mapping that is maybe not obvious or intuitive is that it can only change line shapes not equivalent widths. A dark spot contributes less flux so it has weaker lines, but it also has a weaker continuum. Then when you continuum normalize the equivalent width (i.e. relative to the continuum) remains the same. So for a 'well behaved' observation (only photospheric lines, from a single star, accurate continuum normalization, no veiling, no scattered moon light...) we don't expect the equivalent widths to change, and the equivalent width of the model would match that of the observations. Of course this is not such a well behaved star, but we still want the equivalent widths to be fairly close.

Evelyne (evelyne.alecian@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-05-20 09:44:30

*Thread Reply:* Ok, so indeed we need to choose a strength so that the EW of the intrinsic profile is the same as the observed one.

2020-05-19 18:38:29

A few more general questions and comments. What is the rotation period here? In the plots of the fits, there are some pretty big changes in profile shape over a short period of time, e.g. between phase 0.53 and 0.63. I'm not optimistic we can reproduce that without a different period.

It would be good to try extending the range around the line centre that's being modelled. It's usually good to get at least a pixel or two of actual continuum on either side of the line, and it doesn't look like we are there yet. Guessing from some of the previous LSD profiles it looks like the line goes to ~20 km/s, so I would try calculating to at least +/-25 km/s for DI/ZDI.

Other parameters to experiment with, I would suggest radial velocity and vsini. Maybe the radial velocity should be bit more negative? Hard to guess accurately from the fits. The ring of bright spots sitting on the equator makes me wonder if maybe vsini is a bit off (but given the strong distortions at the line edge there must be some strong equatorial features). Both vsini and radial velocity seem to be in the right ball park, but fine tuning them could influence the map.

2020-05-25 19:58:39

Hmm, if you're running it on a remote server (and don't have X11 forwarding as an option) then running it with the plotting won't work! The renormalization code outputs the renormalized profiles as [fileName].norm and it outputs the continuum polynomial fits as [fileName].contin So you could overplot the unnormalized profile ([fileName]) and continuum fit ([fileName].contin) to check how it's working.

2020-05-25 19:59:28

At least, it should output that if you have

2020-05-25 20:00:06

#Save continuum polynomial? (0=no|1=yes) 1 set in inrenorm.dat

2020-05-25 20:01:38

Then you can change: # Order of the continuum polynomial to be fit # (in the form: y = sum_{i=1,n}(a_i**x^i) ) 3

2020-05-25 20:03:37

That should probably be at least 1, and no more than maybe 4. The goal being to fit the continuum fairly well, while keeping the polynomial well behaved inside the line.

2020-05-25 20:06:20

And you can change the range used to fit continuum through: #vel_start vel_end (line range for EW, km/s, relative to line center Vr below) # This may be different from the range used for continuum calculations, # particularly if the edge of the line is hard to precisely define.
# This should be the same as the range used for ZDI, # while the above velocity range can differ. -100.0 100.0 And here I'd guess that should be something like -20.0 to 20.0, or maybe -30 to 30?

2020-05-25 22:14:17

Sometimes the point of renormalization after LSD is to mitigate the impact of bad blends on the I profile, so it is occasionally useful to go beyond 1st order. However, the other point of caution is that, if the problems in the continuum are due to emission lines, renormalizing might cause more trouble than it solves!

2020-05-27 18:00:12

Good to see the start on magnetic mapping, and exploring vsini a bit. Some comments: • From the fit to Stokes I, it looks like vsini=13.5 km/s is better than 10 km/s. At several phases, there seem to be pixels in the observed line outside model line for vsini=10 km/s. That seems to be supported by the chi^2 you reach in Stokes V? Generally in Stokes I fitting, a change of 0.5 km/s can make a big difference to the map, and you can often get errorbars of a few 0.1 km/s. So the real vsini could easily lie somewhere in between, just closer to 13.5 than 10. • The magnetic field is quite strong, although it looked like Bl went down to -800 G? So it seems pretty plausible that the magnetic map would reach over 1kG in the more intense spots.
• The phasing of the Stokes V profiles doesn't look great. There are some rapid changes, at least in amplitude, e.g. from 1.19 to 0.24, and from 0.79 to 3.88. And the ZDI model is not really managing to fit those. Those phases also have jumps in the line profile shape in Stokes I. I think we should consider alternate (probably shorter) rotation periods. The approach I'd take at this point would be to run a grid search with ZDI fitting Stokes V. So assume a uniform brightness for simplicity, and run a grid of ZDI models (probably with the 13.5 km/s vsini), changing the period slightly between each ZDI model. To start with assume the same target chi^2 for all models, see what periods converge, and what converged periods have the best entropy. You'll probably want a script to run that, and if you decide to go that way I can give you some more detail.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-05-28 10:41:28

To summarize the thread that has been going on these days : Jerome suggested that the best way to estimate the luminosity would be to estimate Av in a (J-H, H-K) diagram using 2Mass magnitudes and dereddening on the T Tauri locus, and then use the J-band magnitude to estimate luminosity. This has been done by Prato+2003 who found L=2.51 +/- 0.29 Lsun for SCrAN. Using this value along with T=4300 +/- 100 K, vsini=13.5 km/s, i=20 deg and a logg=3.75 +/- 0.25, we find a period of 3.66 days, a radius R = 2.85 +/- 0.17 Rsun and a mass M=1.67 +/- 1.16 Msun. Altogether this seems like a rather strong argument in favour of the ~3.6 days period we already found independently. However we cannot neglect the rapid variations pointed out by Catherine and Colin, supported by the smaller Chi² of the fits of the LSD profiles using 1.39 days. I don't know how to make a choice with that and any suggestion would be most welcome !

Jerome Bouvier (jerome.bouvier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-05-28 14:04:57

If it is the narrow component of HeI, the modulation of its radial velocity probably indicates the line comes from a localized hot spot at the stellar surface corresponding to the accretion (post-)shock. In this case, the amplitude of Vrad depends on the spot latitude onto the star and on vsini, as d(Vrad)=2vsinicos(lat). In this case, this would suggest lat=81 deg, i.e., a high latitude hot spot that could indeed correspond to the accretion shock at the foot of magnetic funnel flows controlled by a slightly tilted magnetic dipole (~10 deg.).

But it seems like it would be hard to make that work (and fully convective stars usually have weak to negligible differential rotation). It might be something driven by variable accretion, (e.g. if hot bright material landing at the magnetic pole is a major contributor even to these absorption lines, then as accretion varies, the brightness weighted contribution of the magnetic pole to Stokes V would vary, giving something that doesn't rotationaly modulate). But that's pretty wild speculation! The real answer is I don't know ;)

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-09 11:00:03

A question related to Isabelle’s comment: if you take the shorter period, you will get a closer co-rotation radius. How will it compare then with the truncation radius ?

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-09 11:41:20

According to Bessolaz et al. (2008), the ratio between the truncation radius Rt and the corotation radius Rco is proportional to R^(12/7) and P^(-2/3), if you consider the radius proportional to the period it gives Rt/Rco proportional to P^(22/21). So going from P=3,6 days to P=1,39 days makes the ratio Rt/Rco 2,7 times smaller. With Rt/Rco=0,06 for 3,6 days, it gives Rt/Rco=0,02 for 1,39 days

Jerome Bouvier (jerome.bouvier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-09 12:17:30

I am not sure i understand what do you mean by “if you consider the radius proportional to the period”. Rco depends only on the rotation period (and mass and radius) of the star, this is the location in the disk where the Keplerian velocity is equal to the angular velocity of the star. You can simply derive it from this definition. Rt is set by the equilibrium between magnetic torques (stellar magnetic field) and viscous torques (accretion process) in the disk. It therefore depends primarily on Bstar and Macc, and also on R and M star. It does not depend on the star’s rotation rate, unless you add some assumptions on how B and/or Macc are related to the rotational period (which cannot be ruled out, but would probably be a second order effect). Going from P=3.6d to P=1.39d, rco moves closer to the star by a factor 1.9 while rt is not expected to change.

2020-06-09 18:14:49

Thanks for the copy of your presentation Hugo! For the location of the pole of the dipolar component, the script (it looks like you used) evaluates the l=0 radial poloidal (alpha) component across a model stellar surface and looks for the +ve and -ve extrema. (You can calculate it analytically from the l=1 alpha coefficients, but deriving the expression is a bit of a pain!) It uses the radial dipolar component since the radial and tangential dipolar components are decoupled, but the radial component is usually stronger and usually what you care about further away from the star. What you get depends on the mapping, and in this case the map is pretty non-dipolar (18% of the poloidal field energy, and only 59% poloidal), so it's not so obvious in the map.

2020-06-09 18:25:39

For phasing, that script outputs a position in colatitude and longitude. Phase and longitude run in opposite directions; a confusing consequence of assuming a right handed rotation. So a longitude of 45 degrees = phase 0.875. Phase 0 is where longitude 0 is at the center of the disk of the star (i.e. crossing the line of sight, i.e. 0 rotational Doppler shift). Phase 0 is defined by the input "Julian date for rotation cycle 0". As long as there is no differential rotation, you can pretty much set that to be anything. I guess it was set to the date of the first observation?

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-09 18:27:36

Yes it was, but we did not consider differential rotation yet

2020-06-09 18:34:36

Ok, that seems like a sensible T0, unless there is some other date of particular importance. (With differential rotation, T0 corresponds to the date of the un-sheared image, so it's usually good to use the midpoint of the observations) Then the only tricky bit is the negative sign when converting between longitude and phase.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-09 19:21:22

What would be a date of particular importance ?

2020-06-09 20:30:05

In our case I don't think there is any other obvious date. If there were simultaneous photometry, you could use a date to phase things the same. If there were a planet or secondary star with a known ephemeris, you might use that to inform T0. If the magnetic field were dominantly dipolar you might adjust T0 to be when the pole crosses the line of sight (that is often done for A and B-type stars). But for S CrA N, I don't think it really matters.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-19 15:22:38

Some updates concerning recent developments around the luminosity of SCrAN : Using the method Jerome suggested (J band extinction and magnitude), we have two possible results depending on the distance chosen : • L = 2,03 +/- 0,35 Lsun for d=130 pc • L = 2,84 +/- 0,67 Lsun for d=154 +/- 4 pc First value is the reference Prato et al. (2003), second is the distance estimated by Dzib et al. (2018) who used the Gaïa DR2 data of 21 YSOs in the corona to compute an average distance. This last value is consistent with what we find for SCrAN using its own Gaïa DR2 data (152 +/- 2 pc). However, SCrAN's astrometry may have been disturbed, so the value of Dzib et al. seems like the most reliable.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-22 14:30:25

Considering other bibliography (Galli et al. 2020) that gives also 152 pc for the region of SCrAN, the value of 130 pc by Prato et al. should be discarded, and we adopt hereafter the value of 153 +/- 2 pc that covers the most likely range of distance with the smallest uncertainty. Therefore the luminosity is L=2,805 +/- 0,561 Lsun, Which gives a radius R = 3,01 +/- 0,44 Rsun and a period of 3,86 +/- 1,83 days for an inclination of 20° +/- 5°, which seems to reject the 1,39 days period

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2020-06-23 15:33:12

Thibault Launois who is doing his internship at IPAG with Nadège uses a periodogram slightly different from the one I use (it is a Stacked Bayesian general Lomb-Scargle periodogram described in Mortier et al. (2017)) and I wondered how it would interpret our data for Bl. Here is the result : The different lines correspond to different numbers of observations taken into account to compute the periodogram. I don't know if this could explain the last periodogram, but note also that this 12th observation was the less well fitted in terms of Bl

Correlation matrices should be read as follow : side plots show an average profile surounded by 1-sigma variations. Color intensity corresponds to correlation coefficients ranging from -1 (anti-correlated = blue) to +1 (correlated=green) with a red background corresponding to 0 (no correlation). Dashed white contours correspond to some level of (anti-)correlation. Namely +/- 0.76 here.

2022-09-14 09:12:07

Right, in any case, it seems to indicate that the 5% level is much too tolerant. Would the 0.5% FAP still find significant period in the BC? FAPs are usually calculated assuming white noise and are therefore optimistic. One should considered red noise instead for a proper computation (i.e., successive measurements are not independent, even if not periodic). Rajeev has done that for 1d time-series. I am not sure whether a tool is available for 2d periodograms. You may want to ask him.

Blinova et al. (2016) find in their simulations regimes of chaotic and ordered unstable accretion where multiple periods can appear in the lightcurves, See their figures 3 & 5. It does look similar to what we are seeing here…. In that case the longer period would likely be the stellar rotation period.

2022-09-14 14:54:46

According to the boundaries between the different regimes in the same paper, SCrAN should be in the unstable chaotic regime ( ws=(Rt/Rco)^3/2=0.52 and Rt/R**=3.11 )

Alana Sousa (alana.sousa@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2022-09-14 15:03:42

If I remember well, the unstable chaotic regime is not expected to show periodicities (light curve), and the stable and unstable ordered can be periodic. If so, maybe this system is not in an unstable chaotic regime, right?

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2022-09-14 15:14:04

Well the first figure shared by Catherine is in the case of unstable chaotic regime and displays different periods at the same time for some epochs. Blinova suggests (§5.1) that one corresponds to the rotation period of the star when the others "reflect the frequency of formation of the strongest tongues that reach the surface of the star."

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2022-09-14 15:14:12

well in fact their fig 3 show that the unstable chaotic regime can still show periodicities in the light curve., These periodicities evolve with time but the stellar rotation period seems always visible,

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2022-09-14 15:16:46

the other figure (their fig 5 ) shows the unstable ordered regime and in that case in fact the stellar rotation period is not visible at all… which is a bit strange. An important caveat is that all these simulations are for almost aligned magnetosphere (I think the tilt is 10 degrees). They discuss also in the paper the effect of larger misalignments but I have not had time to read the paper in detail.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 01:00:32

Regarding the truncation radius recovery, this is a tricky one : First of all, here is the formula I use to recover a truncation radius from an observed accretion velocity (v_acc^obs) which corresponds to some velocity in the redshifted absorption of HeI. vinf corresponds to the maximum free-fall velocity of the object (when accreting from infinity) i and L are the inclination of the star and the latitude of the accretion spot, respectively

Rt.png
Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 01:01:15

(With i=23° from GRAVITY and L=80° from ZDI)

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 01:06:33

So the original idea was to take the maximum velocity of the redshifted absorption as v_acc^obs, since it should trace the velocity of the accretion column just before the shock.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 01:10:00

Problem : the median value for this maximum velocity is 330 km/s which yields a "true" vacc (i.e. v_acc^obs / sin(i+L)) of 340 km/s, when vinf = 320 km/s...

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 12:38:18

*Thread Reply:* Beware that your estimated value of Vinf depends on Mstar and Rstar so it is affected with some uncertainty. For Rstar=2 Rsun Vinf=400 km/s.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 01:18:31

We can also derive an other independent value for L with the radial velocity modulation of the HeI NC (Mc Ginnis et al., 2020), but then L=86.2°, which is probably more reliable but it worsens (increases) vacc

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 02:24:42

So what I did is taking the central velocity of the absorption instead of its maximal velocity. This is because I assume that the absorption is broadened (dominantly due to Stark effect, probably ?) to the point that the maximum velocity is no longer relevant for tracing vacc. In that case, all the values of vacc are below vinf, even with L=86.2°. Here is a polar map of the recovered Rt for L=86.2° versus L=80° : each bar represents the reconstructed Rt at its observed phase (assuming P=7.5 days). The central red region is the star. The green dashed circle is the value of Rt derived by ZDI, the blue dashed circle is the radius of the region emitting Brgamma.

Rts800.png
Rts862.png

2023-02-07 12:53:40

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 16:26:14

*Thread Reply:* In a tilted case the hotspot takes the shape of a crescent that tends to be symetric around a line crossing the stellar rotation axis and the magnetic pole. The exact shape depends on the tilt, but the settlement around this line occurs within a few rotation cycles (Romanova et al., 2004, figure attached). So the position of the spot is fixed after a few rotations. That being said, this stands for stable accretion, and hotspots from unstable accretion can be (but not necessarily, according to George) quite different.

Romanova2004.png
Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-02-07 17:56:22

*Thread Reply:* From the figure, the accretion crescent is located on a ring centered on the magnetic pole for misalignments less than 30 degrees. so depending on the phase the accretion region is going to be located at different latitudes (see the two top left figures corresponding to our situation). The accretion crescent is located at latitudes changing from 90 degree (pole) to maybe 70 degrees.

The idea is to make the interpretation more solid regarding this 3.6 days periocity. So far, we have checked the Iron triplet (FeII @ 4924, 5018 and 5169), the Calcium IRT, Helium @ 5876 and 6678. All these lines profiles are in the paper, and any new suggestion is welcome.

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:07:35

Concerning the comments made by Catherine, there are 2 issues that needed to be adressed : First, I previously used 2MASS magnitudes, which happened to take both components of the S CrA system into account, so I changed for the values from Prato et al. (2003) which resolve the two components seperately. This takes the luminosity down to 1.65 +/- 0.9 Lsol (2.77 +/- 0.5 Lsol before).

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:08:02

Then, as Catherine suggested, the veiling might imply an overestimation of the luminosity, so we need to take it into account. Here is what I did :

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:09:40

I assume the flux from either the spot or the star is only proportionnal to their area of emission and the integral of their radiance in a given band (say V).

flux.png
Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:12:53

I also define the veiling in a given band as the flux ratio between the spot and the star. Hence, we can derive a veiling in the J band from our measurements of veiling in the V band, assuming the hotspot and the star are blackbodies at 8000K and 4300K, respectively (see formula bellow, where rj and rv are actually 1+rj and 1+rv).

veiling_form.png
Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:14:33

This yields a veiling rj=0.81, and give a new value for the luminosity : L** = 0.9 +/- 0.5 Lsun

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:17:58

I assumed the veiling in the V band was 2, which is the smallest value we derive and likely the closest to the veiling due to the spot, see Petrov et al. (2011)

Hugo Nowacki (hugo.nowacki@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-18 13:57:08

The value obtained from the unveiled luminosity appears as dashed white line, with its uncertainty as solid white lines.

Catherine Dougados (catherine.dougados@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-19 09:00:35

Also I do not completely follow your reasoning about the estimate of the veiling in J band. First you need to take into account whatever source of excess emission there is over the photospheric one in J band, not just the expected contribution from the spot. Since everything contributes to the overestimation of the J band flux. Then I would use the average veiling in V not the minimum. There is no reason why the J band magnitude you use was taken at a time of minimum veiling. In Sullivan et al. (2009) they estimate an average veiling in H of 4. In Sousa et al. (2023) they show that veilings in J and H are usually quite comparable. So I would take as a best estimate a veiling in J band of rJ=4. Alternatively you can use a range of values (I think in H the veiling varies between 2 and 6).

Evelyne (evelyne.alecian@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-04-19 10:52:01

I agree. The minimum veiling may not be the one corresponding to the Prato measurements (and we probably don’t know what it is). However, even when taking the minimum value, the luminosity is too low so I propose to discuss these new problems in the paper, but to not try to say that the luminosity is for sure the one derived with a veiling of 4 or 6 or 2. The uncertainties are large. We are clearly limited by the large variabilities of the photometric measurements. We are also limited by our understanding of these large variations and their link to the veiling.

Jerome Bouvier (jerome.bouvier@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr)
2023-09-08 08:59:51

https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03888

arXiv.org
Full L- and M-band high resolution spectroscopy of the S CrA binary disks with VLT-CRIRES+
The Cryogenic IR echelle Spectrometer (CRIRES) instrument at the Very Large Telescope (VLT) was in operation from 2006 to 2014. Great strides in characterizing the inner regions of protoplanetary disks were made using CRIRES observations in the L- and M-band at this time. The upgraded instrument, CRIRES+, became available in 2021 and covers a larger wavelength range simultaneously. Here we present new CRIRES+ Science Verification data of the binary system S Coronae Australis (S CrA). We aim to characterize the upgraded CRIRES+ instrument for disk studies and provide new insight into the gas in the inner disk of the S CrA N and S systems. We analyze the CRIRES+ data taken in all available L- and M-band settings, providing spectral coverage from 2.9 to 5.5 $μ$m. We detect emission from $^{12}$CO (v=1-0, v=2-1, and v=3-2), $^{13}$CO (v=1-0), hydrogen recombination lines, OH, and H$_2$O in the S CrA N disk. In the fainter S CrA S system, only the $^{12}$CO v=1-0 and the hydrogen recombination lines are detected. The $^{12}$CO v=1-0 emission in S CrA N and S shows two velocity components, a broad component coming from $\sim$0.1 au in S CrA N and $\sim$0.03 au in S CrA S and a narrow component coming from $\sim$3 au in S CrA N and $\sim$5 au in S CrA S. We fit local thermodynamic equilibrium slab models to the rotation diagrams of the two S CrA N velocity components and find that they have similar column densities ($\sim$1-7$\times$10$^{17}$ cm$^{-2}$), but that the broad component is coming from a hotter and narrower region. Two filter settings, M4211 and M4368, provide sufficient wavelength coverage for characterizing CO and H$_2$O at $\sim$5 $μ$m, in particular covering low- and high-$J$ lines. CRIRES+ provides spectral coverage and resolution that are crucial complements to low-resolution observations, such as those with JWST, where multiple velocity components cannot be distinguished.
Original URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03888
